facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 500 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 500 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 5114, 1963 of Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 597 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 5114, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 597 of 1961.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 4 and respondent No. 6 are trustees of public trust Shri Tricumraiji.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 to 4 and respondent No. 6 are the trustees of a public trust, styled Shri Tricumraiji.

facts.text: In March 1950 trustees mortgaged a house belonging to the trust to Saheba to secure Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: In March 1950 the trustees mortgaged a house belonging to the trust to one Saheba to secure repayment of Rs. 5,000.

facts.text: Mortgagee instituted action against trustees to enforce mortgage, which was compromised.

anchor.surface_text: An action instituted by the mortgagee against the trustees to enforce the mortgage was companypromised,

facts.text: Decree passed that trustees pay Rs. 3,910 by monthly instalments of Rs. 100, default of three instalments makes entire unpaid amount due.

anchor.surface_text: and it was decreed that the trustees do pay Rs. 3,910 due under the mortgage by monthly instalments of Rs. 100 each and in default of three instalments the entire amount remaining unpaid shall become due and recoverable from the mortgagee property.

facts.text: Trustees did not pay the instalments due under the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees did number pay the instalments due under the decree,

facts.text: In execution application by mortgagee, mortgaged property sold and appellant's bid of Rs. 5,000 accepted by executing court.

anchor.surface_text: and in an application for execution by the mortgage  the mortgaged property was put up for sale and the bid of the appellant was accepted for Rs. 5,000 by the executing Court.

facts.text: Trustees applied under O. 21 r. 89 CPC to set aside sale, deposited Rs. 250 (5% purchase money) to appellant and Rs. 6 to mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: The, trustees thereafter applied under 0. 21 r. 89 of the Code of Civil Procedure for setting aside the sale and deposited Rs. 250 being 5 of the purchase-money for payment to the appellant and Rs. 6 for payment to the mortgagee,

facts.text: Trustees claimed mortgagee agreed to give six months for payment and abandon execution application.

anchor.surface_text: claiming that in companysideration o the latter amount the mortgagee had agreed to give to them six months for payment of the mortgage amount, and had agree, in the meantime to abandon the application for execution.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge passed order disposing execution application and directed Rs. 250 paid to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge passed an order disposing of the execution application and directed that Rs. 250 out of the amount deposit, by the trustees be paid over to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant appealed against Subordinate Judge's order to District Court.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against that order by the appellant,

facts.text: District Court reversed Subordinate Judge's order, holding no compliance with O.21 r.89 CPC, no jurisdiction to set aside sale.

anchor.surface_text: the District Court reversed the order holding that since the trustees bad failed to companyply with the requirements of r. 89 of 0. 21 Code of Civil Procedure, the executing Court had numberjurisdiction to set aside the sale.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court under s.115 CPC set aside District Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Gujarat in exercise of powers under s.115 of the Code of Civil Procedure set aside the order of the District Court.

facts.text: Raju J held sale invalid without sanction of Charity Commissioner under s.36 Bombay Public Trusts Act, remanded to District Court.

anchor.surface_text: Raju, J, held that sale of the mortgaged property which belonged to a public trust. without the sanction of the Charity Commissioner being prohibited by s. 36 of the Bombay Public Trusts Act, was invalid, and on that view remanded the case to the District Court

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with special leave against Gujarat High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order, this appeal has been preferred with special leave.

facts.text: Mortgaged property belongs to public trust within Bombay Public Trusts Act.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgaged property belongs to a public trust within the meaning of the Bombay Public Trusts Act.

facts.text: Trustees deposited Rs. 250 for auction purchaser and Rs. 63 for decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the trustees of the trust had deposited Rs. 250 for payment to the auction purchaser. They also deposited Rs. 63 for payment to the decree-holder,

facts.text: Rs. 63 deposit did not satisfy mortgagee's claim, common ground.

anchor.surface_text: but it is companymon ground that the claim of the mortgagee was number satisfied, by that deposit.

facts.text: Mortgagee agreed to abandon execution and wait six months for payment.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged, however, that the mortgagee having agreed to, abandon the execution proceeding and to wait for six months for receiving payment of the mortgage dues from the trustees,

facts.text: District Court right that O.21 r.89 not complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court was, in our judgment, right in holding that the requirements of 0. 21 r. 89 of the Code of Civil Procedure were number companyplied with

facts.text: Question of sanction under s.36 BPTA for court sale not decided except no restriction on civil court execution.

anchor.surface_text: We have numberdoubt, however, that the Legislature did number intend to put any restriction upon the power of the Civil Court executing a decree for recovery of money due from the trust, by sale of the property of the trust.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 5114, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 597 of 1961. V. Goswami, for respondents Nos. 1 to 3. S. K. Sastri, S. P. Nayar for R. H. Dhebar, for respondent No. 7.
Against that order, this appeal has been preferred with special leave. The mortgaged property belongs to a public trust within the meaning of the Bombay Public Trusts Act.
The High Court of Gujarat in exercise of powers under s.115 of the Code of Civil Procedure set aside the order of the District Court.

issues.text: Whether the sale of immovable property belonging to a public trust in execution of a civil court decree requires previous sanction of the Charity Commissioner under section 36 of the Bombay Public Trusts Act

anchor.surface_text: Raju, J, held that sale of the mortgaged property which belonged to a public trust. without the sanction of the Charity Commissioner being prohibited by s. 36 of the Bombay Public Trusts Act, was invalid, and on that view remanded the case to the District Court

arguments.claim: Question of s.36 BPTA sanction not raised before District Court; no illegality or material irregularity in not deciding it, so no interference under s.115 CPC
Precedents of Bombay High Court (Pinjare Karimbhai, Haridas) binding on Gujarat High Court post-reorganisation via Full Bench decision in State of Gujarat v. Gordhandas
arguments.court_reasoning: SC affirms binding nature of inherited precedents and criticizes ignoring Full Bench.

arguments.claim: Single Judge not bound by judgments of other Single Judges, Division Benches of same High Court as it would be contrary to s.165 Evidence Act and judicial oath
arguments.court_reasoning: Subverts stare decisis; single judge bound by coordinate, superior benches for uniformity and certainty; s.165 misapplied.

arguments.claim: Full Bench judgment given on reference ordered by Single Judge or Division Bench has no legal existence
arguments.court_reasoning: Misconceives nature of references; Chief Justice constitutes Full Bench; judgment binding regardless of reference source.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with that view. Obviously the transactions of mortgage, exchange or gift or lease of any immovable property in cls. a b contemplated to be made by the trustees are voluntary transactions, and in the absence of any clear provision in the Act, the expression sale in cl. a would only mean transfer of property by the trustees for a price.

arguments.claim: Agreement to abandon execution does not satisfy O.21 r.89(b) as it does not extinguish decree-holder's claim

anchor.surface_text: This in our Judgment is a futile argument. By abandoning the execution proceeding the claim of the creditor is number extinguished he is entitled to companymence fresh proceedings for sale of the property.

arguments.claim: Single Judge of High Court bound by precedents of coordinate Single Judges, Division Benches, Full Benches, and Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Precedents which enunciate rules of law form the foundation of administration of justice under our -system. It has been held time and again that a single Judge of ,,a High Court is ordinarily bound to accept as companyrect judgments of Courts of companyrdinate jurisdiction and of Division Benches and of the Full Benches of his Court and of this Court.

arguments.claim: Full Bench judgments constituted on reference are binding on other judges of the High Court
Judicial decorum requires Single Judge not to ignore or overrule coordinate/superior precedents but refer to larger bench if disagrees

anchor.surface_text: Judicial decorum, propriety and discipline required that lie should number ignore it. Our system of administration of justice aims at certainty in the law and that can be achieved only if, Judges do number ignore decisions by Courts of companyrdinate authority or of superior authority.

holdings.text: Section 36 of the Bombay Public Trusts Act does not require previous sanction of the Charity Commissioner for sale of public trust property in execution of a civil court decree.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with that view. Obviously the transactions of mortgage, exchange or gift or lease of any immovable property in cls. a b contemplated to be made by the trustees are voluntary transactions, and in the absence of any clear provision in the Act, the expression sale in cl. a would only mean transfer of property by the trustees for a price. Section 36 occurs in Ch. V relating to Accounts and Audit, and is one of the provisions which imposes restrictions on the powers of the trustees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transactions in s.36 are voluntary by trustees; 'sale' means transfer by trustees for price, not court sales; no intent to restrict civil court execution powers.

holdings.text: Section 56B of the Bombay Public Trusts Act does not require notice to Charity Commissioner in proceedings to enforce mortgage decree against public trust property.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, that view also cannot be sustained. A suit to enforce a mortgage or a proceeding to enforce a mortgage decree against property belonging to a public trust is not a suit or proceeding in which a question affecting a public religious or charitable purpose is involved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enforcing mortgage does not involve question affecting public religious or charitable purpose.

holdings.text: Trustees did not comply with requirements of Order 21 Rule 89 CPC as they failed to deposit full proclaimed amount to decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court was, in our judgment, right in holding that the requirements of 0. 21 r. 89 of the Code of Civil Procedure were not complied with and the Subordinate, Judge had no power to set aside the sale held in execution of the decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule requires deposit of 5% to purchaser (fulfilled) and proclaimed amount to decree-holder less receipts (not fulfilled, Rs.63 insufficient).

holdings.text: Mortgagee's agreement to abandon execution and wait six months does not satisfy deposit requirement under Order 21 Rule 89(b) CPC.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged, however, that the mortgagee having agreed to, abandon the execution proceeding and to wait for six months for receiving payment of the mortgage dues from the trustees, abandonment of the execution proceeding was in law equivalent to, payment to the decree-holder of the amount specified in the proclamation of sale for the recovery of which the sale was ordered. This in our Judgment is a futile argument.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abandonment does not extinguish claim; creditor can file fresh execution; rule requires actual deposit, not agreement.

holdings.text: A single Judge of a High Court is bound to follow precedents of coordinate Single Judges, Division Benches, Full Benches of the same High Court, and Supreme Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents ensure uniformity and certainty in law; ignoring leads to conflict; judicial decorum requires following or referring to larger bench.

holdings.text: Full Bench judgments of a High Court, even on reference by Single Judge or Division Bench, are binding on other Judges of the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Chief Justice constitutes Full Bench; judgment binding regardless of reference; misconceives reference process; promotes certainty.

holdings.text: Gujarat High Court inherits and is bound by precedents of Bombay High Court post-reorganisation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Full Bench in State of Gujarat v. Gordhandas holds inherited jurisdiction carries binding precedents.

anchor.surface_text: Jaisri Sahu v. Rajdewan Dubey and Others 1  and the cases referred to therein. If decisions of the same or a superior Court are ignored, eventhough directly applicable. by a Judge in deciding a case arising before him, on the view that every .Judge is entitled to take such view as he chooses of the question of law arising before him as Venkatarama Aiyar, J., observed, the law will be bereft of all its utility if it should be thrown into a state of uncertainty by reason of conflicting decisions.

precedents.cited_proposition: a single Judge of a High Court is ordinarily bound to accept as correct judgments of Courts of coordinate jurisdiction and of Division Benches and of the Full Benches of his Court and of this Court. The reason of the rule which makes a precedent binding lies in the desire to secure uniformity and certainty in the law

Gordhandas 1  that the decision of the Bombay High Court will be regarded as binding since the Gujarat High Court had inherited the jurisdiction. power and authority in respect of the territory of Gujarat. When pressed with the observations made in the two cases cited at the Bar, Raju. J found an easy way out. He observed that the judgment of the Full Bench of the Gujarat High Court had no existence in law.

precedents.citation: Lala Shri Bhagwan Anr. v. Shri Ram Chand and Anr.  3

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, C. J observed In Lala Shri Bhagwan Anr. v. Shri Ram Chand and Anr.  3 . It is hardly necessary to emphasise that consideration of judicial propriety and decorum require that if a learned single Judge hearing a matter is inclined to take the view that the earlier decisions of the High Court, whether of a Division Bench or of a single Judge, need ,to be re-considered, he should not embark upon that enquiry sitting as a single Judge, but should refer the matter to a Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with that view. Obviously the transactions of mortgage, exchange or gift or lease of any immovable property in cls. a b contemplated to be made by the trustees are voluntary transactions, and in the absence of any clear provision in the Act, the expression sale in cl. a would only mean transfer of property by the trustees for a price. Section 36 occurs in Ch. V relating to Accounts and Audit, and is one of the provisions which imposes restrictions on the powers of the trustees.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, that view also cannot be sustained. anchor.surface_text: It was urged, however, that the mortgagee having agreed to, abandon the execution proceeding and to wait for six months for receiving payment of the mortgage dues from the trustees, abandonment of the execution proceeding was in law equivalent to, payment to the decree-holder of the amount specified in the proclamation of sale for the recovery of which the sale was ordered. This in our Judgment is a futile argument.
